body:
I've been experimenting with an idea

[v1.71.0-beta.8835.f8fb9d052.fix-global-config](https://beta.rclone.org/branch/fix-global-config/v1.71.0-beta.8835.f8fb9d052.fix-global-config/) on branch [fix-global-config](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/tree/fix-global-config)

This allows you to override global config for a remote.

So try `_ca_cert = blah` in your config file with the above and see if that works.

Note the leading `_` to signify a global config override. Not totally happy with that choice but haven't been able to think of anything better.

You can override any global variables, but these are the ones which will do something useful in a backend config. (Remember leading _)

```
use_server_modtime
checkers
transfers
low_level_retries
connect_timeout
timeout
expect_continue_timeout
max_connections
disable_http_keep_alives
no_check_certificate
client_cert
client_key
ca_cert
no_gzip
dump
disable_http2
use_cookies
user_agent
headers
bind_addr
traffic_class
```

Thanks for investigating this @ncw!

I can confirm that, with the above build of rclone, I am able to access a WebDAV endpoint by specifying a `_ca_cert` configuration option for that endpoint, in order to choose the correct CA certificate.

So, this patch works for me.

On the `_` prefix, I'm not sure I understand the motivation for identifying global options.  Are you concerned of collisions in the option's namespace; i.e., global and remote-specific (type-specific) options having the same name?

In terms of namespace collisions, one possibility would be to define config names as having a scope; e.g., "global" (global configuration), "remote" (for remote-specific configuration), etc.  When assigning a specific value to some config, the config name could be specified qualified or unqualified; for example,  `global.ca_cert` and `remote.type` are qualified name, while `ca_cert` and `type` are unqualified names.   (The `.` is just an example, the separator could any string; .e.g..,`::`)

Here's a configuration using qualified names

```
[foo]
remote.type = webdav
remote.vendor = other
remote.url = https://example.org:2880/my-data
global.ca_cert = /path/to/CA.pem
```

Here's the same configuration using unqualified names
```
[foo]
type = webdav
vendor = other
url = https://example.org:2880/my-data
ca_cert = /path/to/CA.pem
```

For unqualified names, there would be a standard rule for finding the corresponding qualified name, in case there is any collision; for example, try with `remote` scope, if no a valid config then try with the `global` scope.

That way, configuration is backwards compatible and, if there is a namespace conflict (with the same name available as a global- and remote-specific config) and the standard rule doesn't select the correct name, the user can just write that config assignment using the qualified name.

That said, this approach is rather complex and might confuse people.

> [@albertony](https://github.com/albertony) and [@nielash](https://github.com/nielash) do you have any thoughts about this?

I made a proof of concept for something very similar last year: https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/2697#issuecomment-1888668988 But (as happens all too often with me) I got busy with other things and haven't gotten around to finishing it. ðŸ˜¢ 

On the issue of overriding globals at the remote level, take a look at [this comment](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/2697#issuecomment-1925326234) where I list some possible considerations about that. Among them:

> how conflicting flags would be handled in commands that use more than one remote. For example, suppose I sync two remotes, one of which has `--checkers=8`, the other of which has `--checkers=16`. How many checkers would be used for the sync?

@nielash 

> I made a proof of concept for something very similar last year: [#2697 (comment)](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/2697#issuecomment-1888668988) 

I think what you did and what this does are subtly different. This patch collects up those overridden global vars and applies them to the context used to call NewFs **only**. This makes them great for overriding --ca-cert for example as that context gets passed straight into the fshttp creation, but useless for overriding --inplace (say) as that context is not used for the syncing.

I think being able to override globals on a per backend basis is important so you can set --ca-cert for one remote and not another.

It would be dead easy to change the code to set the global context instead which is what your code does I think (haven't checked it recently) and that would be useful for --inplace 

Perhaps we do need something like @paulmillar idea and namespace the config.

So 

```
[Remote]
type = blah
endpoint = blah # backend config var unchanged 
override.ca_cert = blah # override globals for this backend 
global.inplace = true # really set global vars
```

I think these will be used relatively infrequently but having two types of global var override might be complicated to explain!

> On the issue of overriding globals at the remote level, take a look at [this comment](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/2697#issuecomment-1925326234) where I list some possible considerations about that. Among them:
> 
> > how conflicting flags would be handled in commands that use more than one remote. For example, suppose I sync two remotes, one of which has `--checkers=8`, the other of which has `--checkers=16`. How many checkers would be used for the sync?

That profile code is nice.

Perhaps being able to set

    remote.hard_delete = true

In a profile would be useful too then you could include it into remote definitions.
I've worked this up into a full PR with tests and docs here #8699

issue.title: fs: allow global variables to be overriden or set on backend creation

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
This allows backend config to contain

- `override.var` - set var during remote creation only
- `global.var` - set var in the global config permanently

Fixes #8563

(this also adds the --http-proxy flag which was the initial impetus for this)
